contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Albionbaataridae | fossil_range = [[Late Jurassic]] - [[Early Cretaceous]] | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordata]] | classis = [[Mammal]]ia | ordo = [[Multituberculata]] | familia = '''Albionbaataridae''' | subdivision_ranks = Genera | subdivision = * ? ''[[Kielanobaatar]]''<ref name="Kusuhashi2010">{{Cite journal|author=Nao Kusuhashi; Yaoming Hu; Yuanqing Wang; Takeshi Setoguchi; Hiroshige Marsuoka|year=2010|title=New multituberculate mammals from the Lower Cretaceous (Shahai and Fuxin formations), northeastern China|journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology |volume=30 |issue=5 |pages=1501â€“1514 |doi=10.1080/02724634.2010.501435 |url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~db=all~content=a926985963~frm=titlelink}}</ref> * ''[[Albionbaatar]]'' * ''[[Proalbionbaatar]]'' }} '''Albionbaataridae''' is a family of small, [[extinct]] mammals within the order [[Multituberculata]]. [[Fossil]] remains are known from the Upper [[Jurassic]] and Lower [[Cretaceous]] of Europe and Asia. These [[herbivore]]s lived their obscure lives during the [[Mesozoic]], also known as the "age of the [[dinosaur]]s." They were among the more derived representatives of the informal suborder "[[Plagiaulacida]]". The taxon Albionbaataridae was named by Kielan-Jaworowska Z. and Ensom P.C. in 1994. Members of Albionbaataridae were "Shrew-sized taxa that differ from all other multituberculates in having relatively flat, multi-cusped anterior upper premolars, with 10-14 cusps arranged in three rows, rather than 3-4, rarely up to nine high cusps in two rows, and in having lingual slope of all premolars covered by prominent, subparallel ridges...," (Kielan-Jaworowska & Hurum, 2001, p. 414). ==References== {{reflist}} * Kielan-Jaworowska & Ensom (1994), ''Tiny plagiaulacoid multituberculate mammals from the Purbeck Limestone Formation of Dorset, England''. Paleontology, 37, p. 17-31. * Kielan-Jaworowska Z & Hurum JH (2001), ''Phylogeny and Systematics of multituberculate mammals''. Paleontology 44, p. 389-429. * Much of this information has been derived from [http://home.arcor.de/ktdykes/basmult.htm] MESOZOIC MAMMALS; Plagiaulacidae, Albionbaataridae, Eobaataridae & Arginbaataridae, an Internet directory.
